title: RS21226
content: The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) authorizes federal funding for special education and related services, setting out principles for providing free appropriate public education (FAPE) to children with disabilities. States must identify, evaluate, and provide individualized education programs (IEP) for eligible children. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) requires specific special education and related services for children with disabilities, with parents being partners in planning. Children should be educated with non-disabled peers whenever possible. Procedural safeguards, including due process hearings, are provided. The IEP is crucial for each child with a disability, according to the Department of Education. The Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) mandates special education services for children with disabilities, involving collaboration between teachers, parents, administrators, and related services personnel. An Individualized Education Program (IEP) meeting is scheduled to discuss the child's needs and set goals, including special education services, modifications in testing, and classroom participation. The IEP team must address various aspects such as testing modifications, service start date, transition services, rights at age of majority, progress measurement, and special needs considerations. The Department of Education's sample IEP form is five pages long. The IEP form is five pages long and the Department of Education is constantly reviewing regulations to minimize paperwork burdens. The IDEA Amendments of 1997 reduced paperwork by allowing evaluations to be based on existing data. A study found that over half of special education teachers feel paperwork interferes with teaching. Special education teachers spend over 10 percent of their time completing administrative paperwork, including individualized education program (IEP) tasks and evaluations of children with disabilities. Legislation aims to reduce paperwork burdens for teachers. The Senate report highlights provisions in S. 1248 aimed at reducing bureaucratic paperwork for teachers, including requiring the General Account Office to study special education paperwork and allowing states to use IDEA Part B grants for paperwork reduction activities. Both H.R. 1350 and S. 1248 bills allow local educational agencies to use Part B funds for technology-related casemanagement activities and eliminate school-based improvement plans and the requirement for benchmarks in IEPs. They also permit multi-year IEPs with limitations for children with disabilities who are 18 years or older. Both H.R. 1350 and S. 1248 bills propose changes to IDEA, including limiting complaint time periods, allowing pilot programs for waiver of Act requirements, and mandating model IEPs for consistency across states.
